content.description: Start in the middle of the face on the obvious (really obvious) rail. Move up and slightly right using small side pulls and end in the "water dish" at the top of the boulder. As you pull over the lip to continue moving up, there are some great holds to make that easier and more possible.
content.location: The downclimb is obvious on the backside. Since pads will be on the trail, be aware of mountain bikers and hikers, and make sure to stay out of their way.

content.description: Start on the main rail on two bumps. From there, move up the yellow streak between two large black streaks, utilizing crimps and mono (if you need them). Top out straight above you.
content.protection: A pad and spotter. The landing is fantastic as it is right on the trail.
content.location: The downclimb is on the back left (northeast) side of the boulder when you top out. It will be obvious from the top.

content.description:
This is an instant classic in my opinion!

Start on the obvious jug on the right/center rail of the face. From there, move up using a TERRIBLE left hand gaston. Once solid, you'll need to find a 1/2 pad, one finger crimp to pull to the lip. The topout is kind of slopey but not too bad. The feet are good on the problem or this would be a much higher grade (and I would not be the one posting it).
content.protection: Pads and spotter. That being said, it's right on the trail, so be aware.
content.location: The downclimb is on the the back side of the block. Again, because this boulder is right on the trail, it will be important to look out for hikers and bikers as they should have the right away. When we were there, only one person walked by, so it shouldn't happen too often if I were to guess.

content.description: Start on the undercling rail, and move upward with two-finger pockets and crimp sidepulls. Once you hit the lip, there will be a gigantic jug above the lip you can use to move on top.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter, but the landing is great.
content.location: The downclimb is on the northeast side of the boulder.

content.description: Start on the positive holds, and move up the short slab.
content.location: This route is located on the southeast corner. The downclimb is on the east corner.

content.description: Start on a rail of pockets on the left side of the southwest face, and move up utilizing pockets, an undercling, and a good foot placement. Getting high feet was crucial in getting high enough to reach the sloping topout.
content.protection: The landing is questionable at best. I had 3 pads and a spotter.
content.location: The route is located on the left side of the southwest face of the FPC Boulder. The downclimb is on the northeast face and is pretty easy to get down.

content.description: Start on the far right side of the main face and move upward using crimps, slopers, and a crack system, Top out right about the crack.
content.location: The downclimb is on the back side of the block. Be careful of bikers and hikers, as the boulder is on the trail.
